title: Come as You Are
text: A book about (mostly women's) sexuality. Not quite as... 'hands on' (so to speak) as I expected it to be, but it really was good! Definitely more a self-help book than science though, especially in the second half, which is mostly just the message 'you're normal, love yourself the way you are' repeated in different forms to really drive the point home. To me, where the book shines is the beginning, as it gives a general overview of anatomy and what is normal (spoiler: almost everything).

title: To All the Boys I've Loved Before
text: I watched this because I desperately needed to turn off my brain and I thought this would be one of those shitty Netflix teen romance movies à la The Kissing Booth. I was positively surprised when I actually really enjoyed this movie! So much, in fact, that I watched both sequels in the next 24 hours. (The sequels are good, but not as good as the first one.) Basically, it's got a really good story, a likeable main character and love interest (even though I had a bit of prejudice against Noah Centineo I ended up really loving his performance and character!) and good acting. If you're looking for something light and sweet, and like the 'fake dating' trope, this one's for you!

title: The Bell Jar
text: A modern classic that I've only heard good things about; unfortunately, I was disappointed. This book follows an incredibly unlikeable and ungrateful main character that slowly goes a bit insane - but not in the fun way, more in the suicidal way. The second half of the book is good (but not great), and I read it in a day, but overall this does not deserve more than 3 stars, sorry.

title: Six of Crows
text: I read this because my sister essentially forced me, and because I've heard from so many people that it's amazing. Full disclosure: I usually don't really like YA or Fantasy books. The beginning of this book is such drudgery that I would have DNFed it if that wouldn't have disappointed my sister. Fortunately, it got a lot better around a third in and I really enjoyed the rest of it! The characters are great and the heist story quite exciting. I'm  not sure yet if I will read the sequel.

title: Viewfinder
text: This is a very clever mindfuck-y puzzle game similar to Portal (2) or Antichamber. You basically have to solve puzzles by bending reality with photographs. The concept and visuals were great, unfortunately the story (and some of the voice acting) was lackluster. It's also only about 5 hours long. I recommend it if you like non-euclidean puzzles and don't mind that it doesn't have a compelling story! Bonus: There's a cat.

title: Hello Kitty Island Adventure
text: I was waiting for this game to finally come out on the Switch and I wasn't disappointed! It really is very similar to Animal Crossing, so if you enjoy that you will enjoy this. I wasn't big into Sanrio when I started this but I might be now... The game looks and sounds great, the characters are cute. Some people say this game is grindy, but I highly disagree. In fact, unless you have some quests, there's really not much to do. That and the fact that the characters don't really speak to you (like Animal Crossing villagers do) are the only bad things about this game. Don't expect as much playtime out of it as out of Animal Crossing though, it's a game for young kids and it's very easy.

title: Squid Game (Season 2)
text: I watched Squid Game when it came out like the rest of world, and I enjoyed it, but wasn't obsessed, so I wasn't even sure if I was going to watch the second season. It didn't feel necessary and I had no high hopes for it. After a slow first episode, it really picked up though, and I was very invested. I might have even enjoyed it more than the first season. 001 was my favorite character. I will say no more because of spoilers. Basically, if you liked the first season you will also like this one! It ends in a cliffhanger though, time to wait for Season 3.

title: Subnautica
text: I'm terrified of the ocean, and big things in the ocean, and fish... So this game is a bit like exposure therapy to me. Anyways. It's really good! The exploration aspect is really fun, and the survival aspect is good too (not too difficult, not too easy). This game came out in 2014 but the graphics aged wonderfully, there was not a single moment where I thought something didn't look good. Occasionally, this game has some great humor that reminded me of Portal 2. It's mostly possible to play without using guides/google, but sometimes I was stuck and had to look something up. Also, at around mid-game the difficulty really picks up unless you pick the right upgrades and locations and I almost gave up on the game. Overall, I enjoyed this game just as much as I thought I would, so if you think you might like it, you should try it!

title: My Secret Garden
text: 'My Secret Garden' is a collection of sexual fantasies by real women in the 1970s. Some of the fantasies are quite normal, some very strange and even disgusting. It's a fascinating read about a topic that people (especially women) STILL don't really talk about. I was made aware of this book when I saw the book 'want' by Gillian Anderson on the shelves of a bookstore. 'want' is a modern version of 'My Secret Garden', and it's also an interesting read! Overall, I really liked the 'My Secret Garden', but it gets a bit tedious because some parts are very long, and I found myself skimming over them.

title: Jurassic World: Chaos Theory
text: This is a sequel (after a 7 year time jump) to 'Jurassic World: Camp Cretaceous', which is a children's show set in the Jurassic World universe. As a fan of that universe, I looked into it, not expecting much because I'm not that into children's TV, but I was so pleasently surprised! It's a really good show, and Chaos Theory is even better! (I also like that the characters are now young adults, not kids anymore.) Seriously, the first season of this is PEAK CINEMA, it's sooooo good. So yeah, if you like dinosaurs and/or Jurassic Park, go watch both these shows! I love all the characters :) I'm impatiently waiting for season 3.
